bestBHT.bht: A minister's effectiveness lies in their purity of character, deep understanding of the Gospel, and kind demeanor. Their knowledge is not mere intellect, but spiritual understanding of Gospel mysteries. They demonstrate long-suffering, kindness, and genuine love. A good minister must possess these qualities to do good. Their ministry is rooted in purity and guided by the Holy Spirit, giving testimony to the word of God's grace. Divine prudence enables them to manifest spiritual understanding and navigate the world wisely. Genuine love is the chief fruit of the Spirit and the hallmark of a useful minister.

Henry Alford: I prefer to understand it to mean general purity of character,—unblameableness of life, and singleness of purpose.
In knowledge of the Gospel, in a high and singular degree.
In kindness, a kind and considerate demeanour.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In . . . in," implying not the instrument, but the sphere or element in which his ministry moved.
knowledge—spiritual: in Gospel mysteries, unattainable by mere reason.
long-suffering . . . kindness—associated with 'charity' or 'love', as here.
Albert Barnes: Paul well knew that if he succeeded in the ministry, he must be a good man.
Paul felt that if a minister would do good he must be kind, and gentle to all.
No minister is useful without [love]; no one with it can be otherwise than useful.
John Calvin: Knowledge may be taken in two senses — either as meaning doctrine itself, or skill in acting properly and knowingly.
The Spirit is taken by metonymy, to denote spiritual graces.
The power of God showed itself in many things — in magnanimity, in efficacy in the maintaining of the truth, in the propagation of the Gospel, in victory over enemies, and the like.
Philip Schaff: in pureness... in the Holy Ghost"
probably such manifestations of the power of the truth
giving testimony to the word of His grace.
Archibald T. Robertson: In love unfeigned (εν αγαπη ανυποκριτω). Late and rare word (α privative and υποκριτος, from υποκρινομα) This is the only love that is worth while (Romans 12:9).
John Gill: By pureness...chastity of body and mind, sincerity of heart, and integrity of life.
By knowledge...a walking in wisdom with caution and circumspection.
By love unfeigned...being not in word only, but in deed and in truth towards the brethren, and to all men.
John Wesley: Worldly prudence is the practical use of worldly wisdom: divine prudence is the due exercise of grace, making spiritual understanding go as far as possible.
By love unfeigned — The chief fruit of the Spirit.
Divine prudence is the due exercise of grace, making spiritual understanding go as far as possible.

bhtAttempts.bht: A minister's effectiveness lies in their purity of character, their deep understanding of the Gospel, and their kind and considerate demeanor. The minister's knowledge is not mere intellectual knowledge, but a spiritual knowledge of Gospel mysteries. They demonstrate long-suffering and kindness, and their love is genuine and unfeigned. Paul understood that a good minister must possess these qualities to do good. The minister's ministry is rooted in purity and guided by the Holy Spirit, giving testimony to the word of God's grace. Ultimately, the minister's divine prudence, which comes from grace, enables them to manifest spiritual understanding and navigate the world wisely. Genuine love is the chief fruit of the Spirit and the hallmark of a useful minister.

A minister's effectiveness lies in their purity of character, deep understanding of the Gospel, and kind demeanor. Their knowledge is not mere intellect, but spiritual understanding of Gospel mysteries. They demonstrate long-suffering, kindness, and genuine love. A good minister must possess these qualities to do good. Their ministry is rooted in purity and guided by the Holy Spirit, giving testimony to the word of God's grace. Divine prudence enables them to manifest spiritual understanding and navigate the world wisely. Genuine love is the chief fruit of the Spirit and the hallmark of a useful minister.

A minister's effectiveness lies in their purity of character, deep understanding of the Gospel, and kind demeanor. Their knowledge is not mere intellect, but spiritual understanding of Gospel mysteries. They demonstrate long-suffering, kindness, and genuine love. Their ministry is rooted in purity and guided by the Holy Spirit, giving testimony to the word of God's grace. Divine prudence enables them to navigate the world wisely. Genuine love is the chief fruit of the Spirit and the hallmark of a useful minister.

An effective minister is one who exhibits a pure character and a deep understanding of the Gospel. Their knowledge goes beyond worldly wisdom and delves into the spiritual realm, encompassing the mysteries of the Gospel. They demonstrate patience, kindness, and a genuine love that is not simply superficial, but one that is expressed through actions. Through their ministry, they bear witness to the grace of God, guided by the Holy Spirit. Their divine prudence allows them to navigate the complexities of the world while upholding the values of the Gospel.

An effective minister embodies a pure character and possesses a genuine understanding of the Gospel. Their knowledge transcends mere intellectual reasoning and encompasses the mysteries of the Gospel. They demonstrate patience, kindness, and a sincere love that extends beyond words. Guided by the Holy Spirit, their ministry becomes a testimony to the grace of God. Through divine prudence, they navigate the complexities of the world while staying grounded in the values of the Gospel. Genuine love serves as the ultimate fruit of their spiritual journey.
